field.name: Environmental Health
field.description: The branch of public health concerned with how the environment affects human health, including air and water quality, toxic substances, climate change health impacts, occupational health hazards, and built environment effects on health.

problems.title: Climate Change Driving Surge in Mental Health Crises Including Eco-Anxiety and Heat-Related Psychiatric Emergencies
problems.description: Climate change is increasingly recognized as a profound mental health crisis affecting populations worldwide. Eco-anxiety—chronic fear about environmental doom—has emerged as a significant phenomenon, particularly among youth, with studies showing substantial psychological distress related to climate concerns. The mental health burden extends far beyond anxiety: extreme weather events such as hurricanes, floods, and wildfires cause psychological injury at rates 40 times higher than physical injury. Heat exposure directly impacts psychiatric health, with rising temperatures associated with increased emergency department visits for mental health issues, higher suicide rates, and exacerbation of existing psychiatric conditions. Populations in low-income nations and disadvantaged communities bear disproportionate mental health impacts due to greater climate exposure combined with fewer mental health resources. Climate displacement, loss of livelihoods, and destruction of place-based identity contribute to grief, trauma, and community-level psychological distress. Extreme heat impairs cognitive function, increases aggression, and disrupts sleep patterns across populations. Healthcare systems are inadequately prepared to address this growing crisis, with limited integration of climate awareness into mental health services and insufficient research on effective interventions for climate-related psychological distress.
problems.summary: Climate change causes mental health impacts through eco-anxiety, extreme weather trauma, heat-related psychiatric emergencies, and displacement grief. Mental health consequences of climate events exceed physical injuries by 40:1, with youth and disadvantaged communities most affected.

problems.title: PFAS Forever Chemicals Contamination Creates Pervasive and Persistent Environmental Health Crisis
problems.description: Per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), often called 'forever chemicals' due to their extreme environmental persistence, have emerged as one of the most significant environmental health challenges of the 21st century. An estimated 97% of Americans have detectable PFAS in their blood, with exposure occurring through contaminated drinking water, food packaging, consumer products, and occupational settings. Over 57,000 sites across the United States are suspected of PFAS contamination. These chemicals have been linked to serious health effects including several types of cancer, liver damage, thyroid disease, decreased fertility, hormone disruption, and developmental effects in children. PFAS are virtually indestructible in the environment, do not break down naturally, and bioaccumulate in living organisms. Contamination is particularly severe around military bases, firefighting training facilities, and industrial sites where PFAS-containing foams and products were used extensively. The economic burden is substantial, with cleanup costs estimated in the hundreds of billions of dollars and no fully effective remediation technology currently available. Regulatory frameworks are still developing, with the EPA recently establishing the first drinking water standards for PFAS, but enforcement and cleanup face enormous technical and financial challenges.
problems.summary: PFAS 'forever chemicals' contaminate the blood of 97% of Americans and over 57,000 sites nationwide. These virtually indestructible compounds cause cancer, liver damage, and developmental harm, with no effective remediation technology and cleanup costs in the hundreds of billions.

problems.title: Ambient Air Pollution Causes Millions of Premature Deaths Annually with Disproportionate Impact on Disadvantaged Communities
problems.description: Ambient air pollution remains the single largest environmental health risk globally, causing an estimated 4.2 to 7 million premature deaths annually. Fine particulate matter (PM2.5) penetrates deep into the lungs and bloodstream, causing cardiovascular disease, respiratory illness, stroke, lung cancer, and cognitive decline. Ground-level ozone, nitrogen dioxide, and other pollutants add to the burden. In the United States, while overall air quality has improved, significant disparities persist: low-income communities and communities of color experience substantially higher pollution exposure due to proximity to industrial facilities, highways, and other pollution sources. Climate change is exacerbating air quality challenges through increased wildfire smoke, longer pollen seasons, and more frequent high-ozone days. Wildfire smoke exposure has increased dramatically, with smoke now responsible for up to 50% of fine particle pollution in some regions during fire season. Indoor air quality is an often-overlooked component, with cooking, heating, and household products contributing to exposure, particularly in poorly ventilated housing. Economic costs include direct healthcare expenditures, lost productivity, and premature mortality valued at hundreds of billions of dollars annually.
problems.summary: Air pollution kills 4-7 million people annually through cardiovascular disease, respiratory illness, and cancer. Low-income and minority communities face disproportionate exposure while climate change worsens air quality through wildfire smoke and ozone formation.

problems.title: Drinking Water Contamination and Access Inequities Create Preventable Disease Burden
problems.description: Despite significant infrastructure investments, drinking water contamination and access inequities remain critical public health challenges affecting millions of Americans and billions globally. In the United States, an estimated 7.15 million waterborne disease cases occur annually from public drinking water systems, while 44 million people rely on private wells that are largely unregulated and untested. Contaminants of concern include lead from aging pipes, nitrates from agricultural runoff, disinfection byproducts, emerging contaminants like PFAS and pharmaceuticals, and microbial pathogens. Climate change is exacerbating water quality challenges through increased flooding, drought stress on water supplies, saltwater intrusion into coastal aquifers, and harmful algal blooms. Low-income communities and communities of color face disproportionate exposure to water contamination, with lower-resourced water utilities struggling to meet treatment requirements. The Flint, Michigan water crisis brought national attention to environmental justice in water systems, but similar situations persist in many communities. Infrastructure challenges are immense: the EPA estimates $625 billion is needed over 20 years for drinking water infrastructure alone. Climate migration and population shifts are creating new pressures on water systems not designed for current conditions.
problems.summary: 7.15 million waterborne illnesses occur annually in the US from public water systems, while 44 million rely on unregulated wells. Lead, nitrates, pathogens, and emerging contaminants disproportionately affect low-income and minority communities, with $625 billion in infrastructure needs.

problems.title: Occupational Exposure to Hazardous Chemicals and Emerging Workplace Health Risks
problems.description: Occupational exposure to hazardous chemicals and workplace health hazards remains a major but often underrecognized public health burden. Globally, an estimated 2.3 million workers die annually from work-related accidents and diseases, with chemical exposures contributing significantly to cancers, respiratory diseases, and neurological conditions. Traditional hazards including asbestos, silica, heavy metals, and solvents continue to cause preventable disease, while emerging risks from new technologies, nanomaterials, and novel chemicals outpace regulatory assessment. Workers in agriculture face pesticide exposures, while healthcare workers encounter hazardous drugs and infectious agents. Construction, manufacturing, and mining workers face multiple chemical and physical hazards. Significant gaps exist in cumulative risk assessment—workers are typically exposed to multiple chemicals simultaneously, but regulations assess substances individually. Vulnerable populations including migrant workers, temporary workers, and workers in the informal economy often lack basic protections. Climate change is creating new occupational hazards through heat stress, increased UV exposure, and expanded vector-borne disease risks. Enforcement of existing protections is inconsistent, and many workers remain unaware of their rights or the hazards they face.
problems.summary: 2.3 million workers die annually from occupational diseases and accidents globally. Chemical exposures cause cancers and chronic diseases while emerging risks from new materials outpace regulation. Vulnerable workers lack protections and cumulative exposure assessment remains inadequate.
